trans-unit.source: Provides a mechanism to implement your own thread pool to execute the workflow and manage in-memory timer registration and events.
<xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.WorkflowSchedulerService> is that base class for all classes that create threads that run workflow instances on the workflow runtime engine host.
When implemented in a derived class, initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.WorkflowSchedulerService"></xref> class.
When overridden in a derived class, cancels the scheduled work item with the given timerId.
<xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.WorkflowSchedulerService.Cancel%2A> removes from the pending work items queue a previous request to schedule a workflow instance.
The <xref href="System.Guid"></xref> associated with the existing scheduled thread to cancel.
When overridden in a derived class, this method is called by the runtime to schedule a work item (callback) for a particular instance ID.
Use the <xref:System.Threading.WaitCallback> constructor to create your delegate method to run in the new thread.
A <xref href="System.Threading.WaitCallback"></xref> multicast delegate that represents the method to run.
A <xref href="System.Guid"></xref> that represents the workflow instance.

When overridden in a derived class, this method is called by the runtime to schedule a work item (callback) for a particular workflow instance to be done at the given time (<xref href="System.DateTime"></xref>).
A <xref href="System.Threading.WaitCallback"></xref> multicast delegate that represents the method to run.
A <xref href="System.Guid"></xref> that represents the workflow instance to add.
The <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> to begin running the workflow item.
A <xref href="System.Guid"></xref> that represents the scheduled timer.
